subject: Re: [junit] A method for estimating number of junit test  cases using Cyclomatic complexity
msgSnippet: I am not aware that any accurate models exist. There is one large difference in estimating models between programming with tests and programming without tests.

I am not aware that any accurate models exist. There is one large differenc=
e in estimating models between programming with tests and programming witho=
ut tests. When programming with tests it is generally faster to get to work=
ing code because the tests enable that, eliminating post-code debugging and=
 fixing.

If you are adding tests to existing code, then be aware that writ=
ing those tests will probably take longer than you expect, because the exis=
ting code is probably not designed to be easily tested. Moreover, the tests=
 will uncover refactoring opportunity that will point to time wasted during=
 initial development due to unnecessary duplication.

If you go to your man=
ager with effort estimates to add programmer tests to a project that does n=
ot have them, I wish you the best of luck. You may be shot.

Take care.


>=
So said Selvakumar Ganesan on 2003-08-08 --------------------
>Hi,
>I am tr=
ying to estimate effort for writing a regression test suite based
>on Junit=
 for an existing system. 
>The method used for estimation is very simple (a=
nd possibly very wrong
>too) as described below. I greatly appreciate all i=
nputs and thoughts on
>this. I googled and found no past or present precede=
nt to estimating
>Junit test efforts based on Code complexity measures. I m=
ay have missed
>something important due to my ignorance and relative newnes=
s to Junit
>and estimation. I shall gladly stand corrected by more knowledg=
eable
>folks.
>
>---------------------------------------------
>*Hypotheses=

>The working hypothesis for the effort estimation was "a strong
>corelatio=
n between cyclomatic complexity of existing code and the effort
>to write j=
unit tests for the code".
>
>As a consequence of this hypothesis it is furt=
her purported that "the
>number of independent execution paths (Cyclomatic =
complexity) is equal
>to the number of test methods". This dictates some na=
sty terms to how
>the junit tests must be structured but it is believed to =
be a *resonable
>thing* for estimation purposes.
>
>
>*The estimation metho=
d
>Weighted Methods Per Class (WMPC) was used as a measure of complexity.
>=
WMPC is defined to be "the sum of the complexity of all methods for a
>clas=
s, where each method is weighted by its cyclomatic complexity. The
>number =
of methods and the complexity of the methods involved is a
>predictor of ho=
w much time and effort is required to develop and
>maintain the class. Only=
 methods specified in a class are included, that
>is, any methods inherited=
 from a parent are excluded."
>
>The WMPC measured from the existing codeba=
se was normalized for trivial
>methods like getter and setters. 
>
>The eff=
ort was estimated using a simple formula:
>Total Effort =3D Total number of=
 test methods * Average effort for one
>test method
>
>The Total number of =
test methods is calculated as follows:-
>Total test methods =3D Average WMP=
C of all classes * Number of classes
>
>The Average effort for one test met=
hod (note that this is test method
>and not test case class) was estimated =
from actual efforts.
>
>*Sample calculation
>Number of Classes =3D 973
>Ave=
rage WMPC ~=3D 9 (normalized for getter and setter methods. I used
>Togethe=
r ControlCenter->Metrics for all these measures)
>Average effort per test m=
ethod =3D 2 hours (It is upto the developer to
>distribute the test methods=
 in a test case classes)
>
>Total effort for writing Junit tests =3D (9 * 9=
73) * 2 hrs =3D 17, 514 hours
>=3D 2189 Person Days. 
>(*huh..hmm*. Let the=
 beatings begin. I can't adequaltely express in
>words my manager's bewilde=
red expression on seeing this number. But,
>that's another story.)
>-------=
--------------------------------------
>
>If the general direction of the e=
stimation is correct I would want to
>spend some time on refining the metho=
d to include all those important
>factors I am sure I have missed out above=
. Suggestions and pointers
>towards places I should look more closely to ge=
t a better grip is more
>than welcome. Thank you your time and valuable fee=
dback.
>
>
>Regards,
>Selva.
